sentences.sentence: It's early days for the Conservative leadership race, but it was made clear from the tone and character of the candidates in the opening weeks that this contest isn't for the faint of heart.Pierre Poilievre, the suspected front-runner, isn't holding back from going negative, and has put rivals Jean Charest and Patrick Brown on the defensive.
Typically, attack ads and press releases accusing candidates of lying would be reserved for general elections.

But this is the Conservatives' third go at selecting a new leader since the party lost power in 2015, and it's clear that new strategies are being tested this time around.What makes this communication tactic so interesting, and at times puzzling, is it appears to contradict the basic strategy for winning a party leadership.That strategy, we are told, is twofold.
First, leadership aspirants must recruit new members into the party to ensure they have enough support to survive the first ballot.
Second, candidates must persuade those who became members through other campaigns to assign them a second- or third-preference ranking.

In doing so, leadership contenders can win by consolidating a majority of votes on subsequent ballots.You'd think that launching highly personalized attacks against other viable candidates would limit Poilievre's ability to attract down-ballot support.
Yet, the conventional strategy assumes that every member will assign a ranking to each candidate.Recent leadership contests demonstrate that this is not necessarily true.
In 2020, approximately 174,000 members voted on the first ballot.
The number of members who marked a third preference fell to 154,000, after Leslyn Lewis and Derek Sloan were dropped.

In other words, more than 10 per cent of the members who participated in the 2020 contest found Erin O'Toole and Peter Mackay so unpalatable that they refused to assign them any ranking.Poilievre's strategy of attacking Brown and Charest's record on contentious issues like carbon pricing will likely result in some members leaving them off the ballot entirely.
An obvious risk with this maneuver is that it may have the opposite effect on Poilievre.

Members recruited into the race by Brown and Charest could be just as unlikely to view Poilievre as a candidate they could support.Yet recent changes to the Conservative leadership process could mitigate this risk for Poilievre.
Previous contests assigned 100 points to each riding.
Rather than needing a simple majority of votes, candidates needed a simple majority of points to win the leadership.
The first candidate to win more than 16,901 points became the party leader.This time around, the Conservatives have modified how membership ballots are translated into points.
The new rules specify that ridings must have 100 membership votes in order to get 100 points.
Ballots cast in ridings that fail to reach this threshold are only counted at face value, whereas in the past, 10 ballots would be counted as 100 points.

Most of the ridings with less than 100 votes have traditionally been located in Quebec.With the new rules in place, it is plausible for a candidate to win on the first ballot by securing 80 per cent of the points in Western Canada, 50 per cent of the points in Ontario and 20 per cent of the points in Atlantic Canada.

Generating this distribution of first ballot support - which would add up to slightly more than 15,000 points - might be enough to win.Poilievre's team has made a tremendous gamble in adopting a combative communications plan.

By labelling other Conservative leadership aspirants as liars, untrustworthy or worse, the risk is that Liberals could use this to sow further divisions within the party.In the event the strategy does pay off, however, Poilievre will be in a much stronger position to lead, one not possessed by former leaders Andrew Scheer or Erin O'Toole, for their victories only came after consolidating down-ballot support.

Securing a mandate on the first ballot may prove to be the essential ingredient for instilling the culture of discipline that helped former prime minister Stephen Harper bring the Conservatives to power.National PostJosie Sabatino is a senior consultant at Summa Strategies and the former director of communications for Erin O'Toole.
